Posts.Content: Thank you all for your advice. I was going in for a PSA test this morning, but since I had a DRE yesterday, I will follow HighlanderCFH's advice and wait a few days. Thank you for that! Anyway, during the initial doctor visit (UCLA), while stressing that it was "probably not cancer", I asked (hypthetically) what he would advise his brother (if he had a brother). He said that he would advise him to go ahead to have the biopsy done. However, after reading the remarks posted here, I think I'll wait until next week and have another PSA test taken. If the results are elevated, then I will most likely get it done. If the results are somewhat static, then I'll wait until my next appointment in July. Opinions?
Posts.Title: Looking for advice

Posts.Title: Looking for advice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider You might want to consider getting the "4 K Score" done, a new type of genetic test which might clarify your decision on this. That's not the only one I think, it costs $400 and may or may not be covered by insurance. If you don't have insurance, a biopsy might be $4000 or more, including the pathologist fee, it would seem to be a real good choice if you're in that situation. I'm blessed with excellent PPO insurance, but I will look into a "4 K Score". Thank you.
Posts.Title: Looking for advice

Posts.Content: 4K score test was taken a couple of months ago ($600), which led to a second opinion at Cedars-Sinai. The doctor performed another DRE and an ultrasound in his office. He felt that the nodules were most likely calcium, but he recommended an MRI for further review. Today, I met with the doctor to review the MRI results. Based on the radiology, the doctor graded the prostate a "4" meaning that there was a 70% chance that there was some cancer involved. He recommended a biopsy (with propophol!). Based on my general health, weight, age, etc., he felt that although I fell into the 70% probability range, there was also a 30% chance that the biopsy would be negative. So, I'm really back where I started! UCLA wanted to perform "barnyard medicine" by doing the biopsy in the office with an injection of lidocaine (I freaked out about that). At least Cedars will put me under and I will avoid most anxiety. Based on the probabilities stated above, are there any opinions out there of similar situations? More info: Recent PSA 1.7 Prostate is not enlarged. Doctor stated that even with those good numbers and based on the other findings, cancer occurs in about 25% of similar cases.
Posts.Title: Looking for advice

Posts.Title: Looking for advice

Posts.Content: I am a 62 year old male (aging athlete) in good health. The last blood work that I had done in January of this year showed a PSA of 1.1 I have not been experiencing any troubling symptoms of any kind, but I decided to keep on top of my health and visit a urologist for a general check up. After prodding around for what seemed like an eternity, he sat down and told me that he felt nodules on my prostate which he considered "abnormal". He then gave me these statistics based on my previous PSA test results, my age, weight, lifestyle, and general health: There was a 2% chance that the nodules were aggressive in nature. There was a 12% chance that the nodules were cancerous, but not aggressive in nature. There was a 86% chance that the nodules were not cancerous, but something else. He then explained to me what was involved in a biopsy and the fact that a biopsy would be the only way to determine if the nodules were cancerous. Being a squeemish baby, I was more horrified at the thought of the biopsy than the possibility of cancer!- well not really, but I digress. My question to forum members is this: Should I have the procedure done or wait until my next appointment (July 2017)? I am going tomorrow for another PSA test which should make this decision a little easier (hopefully not elevated!) My second question is: There is a 98% chance that a biopsy will result in the prognosis of either "clear" or "watch and wait". Aren't the odds WAY in my favor? What would you do?
Posts.Title: Looking for advice

Posts.Content: I just got my results back from a 4K test. The doctor says that there is a 12% chance of "aggressive" cancer if a biopsy is performed (and he recommends a biopsy). Apparently, the doctor noticed nodules on the prostate during the initial DRE last may. The recent test shows PSA still low 1.1. I have a lot of anxiety about a biopsy. Any advice out there?
Posts.Title: Recent 4K result

Posts.Content: Thanks for the reply. Correction- my PSA was 1.8 (still low). Free PSA was 23%. Should I get a biopsy or just watch and wait with periodic PSA testing?
Posts.Title: Recent 4K result

Posts.Content: Good advice
